DataElement.preferredDefinition: the grade from an assessment method used in the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the grade from an assessment method used in the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation.

Concepts.definition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation.

Property.preferredDefinition: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

Concepts.definition: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: ECOG CRF:Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality for the Child-Pugh hepatic disease classification.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 45% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.

Concepts.definition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 45% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/26/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 80% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 100% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.

Concepts.definition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 100% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 45% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.: A natural number greater than 11 and less than 13 and the quantity that it denotes.

Concepts.definition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 45% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis. ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 45% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.: A natural number greater than 9 and less than 11 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of nine and one.
